con.para: Everything around us is made of tiny particles called atoms. At the center of an atom is the nucleus, which contains protons and neutrons, while electrons zoom around the outside.
Protons are positively charged, neutrons have no charge, and electrons are negatively charged. The number of protons in an atom decides what element it is.
The atomic mass is the total number of protons and neutrons in the nucleus. Different elements have different atomic masses depending on the number of protons and neutrons they contain.
Some atoms are unstable and break down over time, releasing energy. This process is called radioactivity, and it happens in the nucleus.
There are three main types of radiation: alpha, beta, and gamma. Alpha particles are the heaviest, beta particles are fast-moving electrons, and gamma rays are energy waves.
Alpha radiation releases particles with two protons and two neutrons. It's big and heavy, but it can be stopped by something as light as paper!
Beta radiation is made of fast-moving electrons. It can pass through paper, but something thicker, like aluminum, can stop it.
Gamma rays are waves of energy, not particles. They can pass through almost anything, even metals, but thick lead can block them.
Nuclear energy comes from the nucleus of an atom. It can be released by breaking apart the nucleus (fission) or by joining two nuclei together (fusion).
In nuclear fission, a large atom, like uranium, splits into two smaller atoms. This releases a lot of energy, which can be used to make electricity.
In nuclear fusion, two small atoms, like hydrogen, combine to form a larger atom. Fusion powers the sun and gives off even more energy than fission!
Nuclear physics isn't just for power plantsâ€”it's also used in medicine (for X-rays) and to keep our food fresh with radiation.
